questions.question: Which of the following best describes the primary purpose of a Sequence Diagram in UML?
questions.option_a: A. To depict the static structure of classes and their relationships
questions.option_b: B. To model the flow of control between actors using decision nodes
questions.option_c: C. To illustrate time-ordered interactions among objects in response to a specific scenario
questions.option_d: D. To represent data flow between system components
questions.explanation: Sequence Diagrams are behavioral UML diagrams that show how objects interact in a time-ordered sequence to carry out a specific functionality or use case.

questions.question: In a Sequence Diagram, what does an Activation Bar (or Execution Occurrence) represent?
questions.option_a: A. The lifetime of an object from creation to destruction
questions.option_b: B. A condition that must be true for a message to be sent
questions.option_c: C. The period during which an object is performing an action or processing a message
questions.option_d: D. The return path of a message from a receiver to a sender
questions.explanation: An Activation Bar is a thin vertical rectangle on a lifeline that indicates when an object is active—i.e., executing a method or handling a message.

questions.question: Which types of messages are valid in UML Sequence Diagrams?
questions.option_a: A. Synchronous, asynchronous, return, and self messages
questions.option_b: B. Broadcast, multicast, unicast, and return messages
questions.option_c: C. Request, response, acknowledgment, and error messages
questions.option_d: D. Signal, event, trigger, and callback messages
questions.explanation: UML Sequence Diagrams support synchronous (solid arrow with filled head), asynchronous (solid arrow with open head), return (dashed arrow), and self messages (looped to the same lifeline).

questions.question: In a Sequence Diagram using the Boundary-Controller-Entity (BCE) architectural pattern, which of the following interactions is NOT allowed?
questions.option_a: A. Actor → Boundary
questions.option_b: B. Boundary → Controller
questions.option_c: C. Controller → Entity
questions.option_d: D. Actor → Entity
questions.explanation: According to BCE rules, actors must interact only with Boundary objects; direct interaction between an Actor and an Entity violates the separation of concerns in this pattern.

questions.question: What does an ALT fragment represent in a UML Sequence Diagram?
questions.option_a: A. A set of messages that execute repeatedly based on a condition
questions.option_b: B. An optional interaction that occurs only if a guard condition is true
questions.option_c: C. A choice between mutually exclusive interaction paths, each with its own guard condition
questions.option_d: D. A reference to another complete sequence diagram
questions.explanation: An ALT fragment models conditional logic (like if-else or switch statements), where exactly one operand (path) executes based on which guard condition evaluates to true.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key characteristic of asynchronous messages in Sequence Diagrams?
questions.option_a: A. They require the sender to wait for a response before proceeding
questions.option_b: B. They are depicted with dashed arrows and open arrowheads
questions.option_c: C. They allow the sender to continue execution without waiting for a reply
questions.option_d: D. They can only be sent between Boundary and Controller objects
questions.explanation: Asynchronous messages do not block the sender; the sender continues its execution immediately after sending the message, making them suitable for concurrent or event-driven systems.

questions.question: In a Sequence Diagram, lifelines are used to:
questions.option_a: A. Represent the inheritance hierarchy among classes
questions.option_b: B. Show the duration and timing of object existence and activity over time
questions.option_c: C. Model database tables and their foreign key relationships
questions.option_d: D. Indicate the physical location of system components
questions.explanation: A lifeline is a vertical dashed line extending downward from an object or actor symbol, representing its existence and participation in the interaction over time.

questions.question: Which UML diagram types are classified as Interaction Diagrams?
questions.option_a: A. Class Diagram and Object Diagram
questions.option_b: B. Sequence Diagram and Communication Diagram
questions.option_c: C. Activity Diagram and State Machine Diagram
questions.option_d: D. Component Diagram and Deployment Diagram
questions.explanation: UML Interaction Diagrams include Sequence Diagrams (emphasizing time ordering) and Communication Diagrams (emphasizing object relationships), both modeling dynamic behavior.

questions.question: Consider a Loop fragment in a Sequence Diagram labeled 'loop [i = 1 to 5]'. What does this indicate?
questions.option_a: A. The enclosed messages execute exactly 5 times
questions.option_b: B. The loop runs until a boolean condition becomes false
questions.option_c: C. Five parallel threads execute the same messages simultaneously
questions.option_d: D. The system will crash if i exceeds 5
questions.explanation: A Loop fragment with 'i = 1 to 5' specifies a definite iteration count—here, the interaction occurs exactly five times, analogous to a for-loop in programming.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a REF fragment in a Sequence Diagram?
questions.option_a: A. To define a recursive call within the same object
questions.option_b: B. To reference an interaction defined in another diagram for modularity
questions.option_c: C. To indicate a failed message delivery
questions.option_d: D. To show alternative execution paths based on runtime data
questions.explanation: A REF (Reference) fragment allows a sequence diagram to refer to a reusable interaction defined elsewhere, promoting clarity and reducing redundancy in complex models.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common error when constructing Sequence Diagrams?
questions.option_a: A. Using solid arrows for return messages
questions.option_b: B. Placing activation bars above the lifeline
questions.option_c: C. Omitting messages that are essential to the scenario flow
questions.option_d: D. Labeling actors with lowercase names
questions.explanation: Missing critical messages breaks the logic of the interaction and misrepresents system behavior, making it a frequent and significant modeling error.

questions.question: In the context of Sequence Diagrams, what does a self message typically represent?
questions.option_a: A. A message sent from one actor to another
questions.option_b: B. An internal method call or recursive operation within the same object
questions.option_c: C. A response from a database entity to a controller
questions.option_d: D. A broadcast to all active objects in the system
questions.explanation: A self message is a call that an object makes to itself, often representing internal processing, helper method invocation, or recursion.

questions.question: Which statement about the OPT fragment is correct?
questions.option_a: A. It executes multiple alternative paths in parallel
questions.option_b: B. It represents an optional interaction that occurs only if its guard condition is true
questions.option_c: C. It must always include an 'else' clause
questions.option_d: D. It replaces the need for all other combined fragments
questions.explanation: An OPT fragment models a single optional sequence of messages that executes only when its guard condition is satisfied—equivalent to a simple 'if' statement without an 'else'.

questions.question: According to BCE (Boundary-Controller-Entity) rules in Sequence Diagrams, which of the following is a valid communication path?
questions.option_a: A. Entity → Boundary
questions.option_b: B. Controller → Actor
questions.option_c: C. Entity → Controller
questions.option_d: D. Boundary → Entity
questions.explanation: While the primary flow is Actor → Boundary → Controller → Entity, responses can flow back, so Entity → Controller is valid during return paths or callbacks.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a key component of a Sequence Diagram?
questions.option_a: A. Lifeline
questions.option_b: B. Activation Bar
questions.option_c: C. Class Attributes
questions.option_d: D. Actor
questions.explanation: Class attributes are part of Class Diagrams, not Sequence Diagrams, which focus on runtime interactions rather than static structure.

questions.question: In a Sequence Diagram, how is a synchronous message visually distinguished from an asynchronous one?
questions.option_a: A. Synchronous: dashed arrow; Asynchronous: solid arrow
questions.option_b: B. Synchronous: solid arrow with filled arrowhead; Asynchronous: solid arrow with open arrowhead
questions.option_c: C. Synchronous: labeled with 'async'; Asynchronous: labeled with 'sync'
questions.option_d: D. Synchronous: horizontal line; Asynchronous: diagonal line
questions.explanation: Synchronous messages use a solid arrow with a filled (closed) arrowhead, indicating the sender waits; asynchronous messages use an open arrowhead, indicating non-blocking behavior.

questions.question: Which evaluation criterion is essential for a high-quality Sequence Diagram?
questions.option_a: A. Inclusion of every possible system object
questions.option_b: B. Realistic and logically ordered flow of events
questions.option_c: C. Use of at least five different combined fragments
questions.option_d: D. Color-coding of message types
questions.explanation: A valid Sequence Diagram must reflect a realistic, coherent sequence of interactions that align with system requirements and use case logic.

questions.question: What is a key limitation of overusing stereotypes like <<Boundary>> or <<Entity>> in Sequence Diagrams?
questions.option_a: A. It increases execution time of the modeled system
questions.option_b: B. It can obscure the actual interaction logic with unnecessary notation
questions.option_c: C. It violates UML syntax rules
questions.option_d: D. It prevents the use of activation bars
questions.explanation: While stereotypes add clarity when used appropriately, excessive or inconsistent use can clutter the diagram and distract from the core message flow.

questions.question: Which statement correctly describes the role of an Actor in a Sequence Diagram?
questions.option_a: A. It represents an internal system component that processes data
questions.option_b: B. It must always be a human user
questions.option_c: C. It exists outside the system boundary and initiates or receives messages
questions.option_d: D. It can directly modify Entity objects without a Controller
questions.explanation: An Actor in UML is external to the system (could be a person, another system, or hardware) and interacts with the system by sending or receiving messages.

questions.question: In a Sequence Diagram, what does a dashed arrow with an open arrowhead typically represent?
questions.option_a: A. A synchronous call
questions.option_b: B. An asynchronous call
questions.option_c: C. A return message
questions.option_d: D. A self-call
questions.explanation: Return messages—whether explicit or implied—are conventionally shown as dashed arrows with open arrowheads, indicating the flow of control or data back to the sender.
